title: servo controlled bed leveling probe holder

description.text:
I recently added the bed leveling function to my 3d printer
And after 4 prints I discovered that the probe did not function properly due to the heat of the bed and nosel and eventually broke down.lets see how could I solve that problem and have been experimenting with the sevro/mechanical system with a probe instead of a mechanical endstop and how to combined both Systems and this is my result of a combination of both systems. Now i ownly have to convince the firmware but thats gonna take a while I guess..

but i beleve there are a whole lot of supper Intelligent people Out there ho can help me/us solve that litle Issue

title: Mk8 Spring loaded Drive Block Replicator 1 / Duplicator 4 / FlashForge / CTC

description.text:
Adapted version of ivcs fillament drive block: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:62510 Update: DriveBlockBase V9 allows printing of NinjaFlex and other flex filament and is tested on WanHao Duplicator 4 and CTC Dual with NinjaFlex. Please see attached pictures and read instructions for some tips how to configure your slicer right to not blame the drive block for mistakes you make. Original idea was to modify it that it can handle bigger draw rolls, like used on Wanhao Duplicator 4, which has a 11mm cylindric gear-wheel with and a 12mm ball bearing draw roll with a grooved surface and a shaft diameter of 3mm.
I read a lot of broken ball bearing shafts and because 3mm is a very weak shaft diameter if you use a strong spring I decided to add a M3 pan head screw as shaft instead. In addition all spring loaded drive blocks I know have overhanging ejection units on the outer sides. I think this might disturb some ideas to use the extra head room we have in the printer especially to the left to install a bigger heated build plate. On top of the extruders here we have some space left, which I decided to use for the ejection buttons. I had several stages of development of this unit but I run my current version since 6 months now, without any issues and decided to release it now as stable. Of course this mod should also work with the Original Replicator and 623ZZ ball bearings ivc recommends. See instructions tab for information how to print and what extra parts you need.

Parts:
  • 1x M3 x 16mm Flat Head Cap Countersunk Hex Screw
  • 1x M3 x 8mm Flat Head Cap Countersunk Hex Screw
  • 1x M3 x 6mm Flat Head Cap Countersunk Hex Screw
  • 1x Compression Spring, 0.360"OD 0.276"ID 0.630"-0.900"L (9mm OD x 7mm ID x 16-22mm L), 32lbs/in spring rate
    (I bought a too long Spring named normal strenght at Hornbach in Germany and cutted it to a lenght of 24mm)
    if you dont have a ball bearing draw roll with an inner diameter of 3mm in your printer already:
  • 1x Ball Bearing, 3mm ID x 10mm OD x 4mm Width, typ. 623ZZ bearing
    • My advice is to print it with ABS (better heat resistance than PLA if you want to print ABS later on with it) .
    I printed all of the parts with a layer height of 0.10mm, 2 shells and a solid infill of 100% which makes it more stable.
    ONLY for the Base unit you will need supports and should switch them off if you print the Levers and Covers. Notes concerning NinjaFlex prints:
  • Never print faster than 30mm/s
  • set rectraction to zero
  • disable any slowdown options for layers under a given time or bridging
  • Extruder temperature ~235°C
  • Heatbead temperature ~50°C
  • directly print on glas or mirror glass without any addons!
  • don't use the fillament loading option inside printer menu cause it's loading the fillament to fast. Manually load via your slicers USB control interface or simply just push carefully the fillament into the nozzle with pressed drive block eject button and it's loading the fillament while doing the start code wipeing or Simplify3Ds skirt layer.
  • keep nozzle distance from heatbed farer away than on normal prints
  • do not print with a layer hight of less than 0.2mm
  • if your extruder clicks while printing it will fail the print and you did not follow my upper recommendations or your nozzle distance was still too low. Remove the extruder fan and heat sink and fix the fillament pushed together directly above the nozzle.

comments.author: raffo333

comments.text: Construction was in metric system and printing was done without scaling. The fitting of the stepper ring is very tight. Depending on the quality of your print you might need a few scraping turns with a carpet knife to make it fit closely. You might also nee a drill to expand the drill holes a little. My target was to have a real close fit to avoid backlash which would cause unnecessary higher forces. Because of differences in print quality I took the risk of having to use a drill and a carpet knife for the perfect finish.

description.text: PAC-MAN desk pen :)

Here's a second version of my Waves spinner. I reduced the distance of the satellite bearings from the center, so the overall spin radius is reduced by ~5mm to make this work also for smaller hands. The overall look still resembles the original Waves spinner very closely. To better preserve the rounded edges I recommend printing the split design, then glue the 2 halves together, or just rely on the friction of the bearing outer surface to hold the 2 halves together.

The attached picture shows the 2 versions for comparison. Original Waves spinner is on the left.

description.text:
In my day to day I always come across surfaces where the angle is hard to obtain. I wanted a quick way to obtain and translate angle measurements and still have the device fit in my tool box or pocket.

How do i use the angle translator?

  • Simply open the tool until both halves are resting firmly on the two surfaces you wish to measure.
    -Remove the tool and use the top edge of the top half and the bottom edge of the bottom half to translate the acquired angle onto paper, wood or metal. Any surface really.

    How do I assemble the angle translator?

  • Clean off any support material until the two parts fit together. I use a 8-32 shoulder bolt with a length of 45mm and a matching nut to mate the two sections. Thread the bolt through and insert the nut. Simple.

Printer:

Anet A6

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.1mm

Infill:

25% Tetrahedral

Notes:

Lay all parts flat with text facing up. The 3mf file has everything set up for you if you wish to just import it into your slicer.

This is to extend the battery base. Looks like HK trifecta has a design flaw, where it is really hard to strap a battery because only the front part of the battery touches the bottom of the tri and the second half hangs in the air. With strap being at the edge of the base.

this will make the strap appear in the middle of the mounting base.

Print with 5% infil to make it as light as possible. Attach with thin double-sided duck tape.
Attach velcro on the outside to extend the battery gripping surface.

Because 5% of infil is virtually hollow..make sure you print with plenty of cooling and slow speeds over the overhangs.

Run setup without LS filter by plugging VTX directly to battery balance plug. Saves weight and gives you clear video signal. Do it on most of my FPV birds.

Good luck.

3D model for my Raspberry PI PC look-a-like. found here: (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2793764)
The glowing photograph is of the laser cut version I created for my raspberry pi H440 case mod project.(http://imgur.com/gallery/PvjBO) and I have not yet released those files, but this is the 3d printable version which is almost as close as I can get to the same scale and dimensions.

I have not verified how well the detail will print on any given printer. I highly suggest you print it with really thin layers, thin walls, and out of a clear/transparent/glow-in-the-dark filament

The two holes in the backside are for LED's to be inserted inside, and once the details are painted it will add a really amazing and cool effect.

LOOK FORWARD TO:

I'm going to remix this a little in the near future to make it a USB drive case instead of a LED model.

I'm going to give it a few edits as I see how well it prints to make it more user friendly.

I'm going to include a larger version (probably double the size) for people to print and play with.

I'm going to include an enlarged, hollow, fan less version, for the possibility of someone wanting to print a large sized fake gpu cover for other projects.

title: Stereoscopic Camera Mount for Kodak Pixpro SP360 4K
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Side-by-side stereoscopic mount for a pair of Kodak Pixpro SP360 4K cameras. The interocular separation distance is adjustable between ~60mm and ~80mm.

Cameras can be mounted directly onto the flat plate, or mounted with the second part, which provides an extra registration pin as well as vertical guide-posts for the back of the camera.

Both parts have access openings for the SD card and USB/HDMI ports on the bottom of each camera. The flat mounting plate has a 1/4" center hole with recessed space for a 1/4-20 machine screw hex nut, 3/16" across the flats.

I may strengthen the flat mount with a metal plate, but even with less flex in the mount, I recommend checking the resulting footage for roll between the eyes and manually correcting any difference. Adobe Premiere CC has a VR Projection video effect that allows manual reorientation of VR footage.

title: Art Deco Knobs for 6mm 1/4inch rotary encoders

description.text:
These are a few knobs I ended up making for my DecoTime timer. They are currently sized for a keyed rotary encoder or variable resistor. The holes are 6mm (1/4 inch), and keyed to 4.5mm, a common standard size. I made them a tight fit, so you may want to scale them up a bit, or be ready to sand them down a bit.

A few are art deco designs to go with my art deco timer DecoTime (http://coolate.com/blog/coolate-pages/deco-time-angular-timer/).

They might make a good starting point for others.

Here is what I used them on:

description.text:
This is a propeller spinner that I developed for my 3Dlabprint Spitfire using this motor from Horizon Hobby https://www.horizonhobby.com/480-brushless-outrunner-motor--960kv-pkz4416

I originally scavenged it out of my Icon A5 from the same manufacturer.

There are two different noses. One with a hole for an M2 flathead screw to secure the nose to the prop assembly, and the other with no hole that can be glued in place. The no hole option is probably okay, due to the fact that if you land badly enough to break the prop, your likely in for a partial fuselage rebuild.

One of the advantages of this spinner is the extra distance on the back side. Even if it is too deep for your application, you can set it a specified amount below the print bed for the amount of clearance needed.

SPECIFICATIONS:
It is 18mm between the prop face and the back of the spinner. There is 2mm between the prop face and the back where the prop adapter mates to, and will clear a 15mm diameter prop adapter. The bore is 6.35mm. The diameter at the back of the spinner is 43mm. 31mm from the prop face to the tip of the spinner.

Hier jetzt die neue, verbesserte Version meines Mecreator2 Fan duct in der Version 4

Nachdem der Stock-Fan-duct vom Mecrator2 sich als echte Enttäuschung herausgestellt hat, habe ich mir selber einen entworfen.
Der Kühler ist in 4 Teile aufgeteilt, wovon später der Bauteilkühler und der Adapter miteinander verklebt werden müssen. Ich habe dazu Sekundenkleber genommen.
Alles wird ohne Supportmaterial gedruckt. Ich habe jetzt in der Version 4 im Kühlkanal an der Deckfläche extra nochmal ein paar Supportkanten eingebaut, welche ein herunterfallen der Top-Layer verhindern werden. Der Adapter wurde auch nochmal überarbeitet. Den Clip habe ich entfernt und statt dessen die Schrauben vom Originalkühler verwendet. Zusammen mit den beiden Distanzhülsen sitzt der Kühler jetzt bombenfest.
Druckt ihn mit 0,2mm Auflösung und 2 Perimetern. 100% Infill und alles sollte klappen.
Bei fragen könnt ihr euch gerne an mich wenden.

Viel Spaß beim nachdrucken.

Poop: Your turn is skipped for two rounds

Sleep: Turn skipped for one round

title: Lego Man with Hat and House

description.text:
This is a project I've made for my IED class based on the principles of reverse engineering. My partner and I decided to reverse engineer a lego man with add improvements such as a ball-socket mechanism at the arms to allow more movement in the figurine. However, we made the error of forgetting to add the improvements thus have just in the end created a simple lego man. The lego man has a new hat however along with a small house to live in. The print itself worked out pretty well, there seemed to be some error with the hat that needs to be adjusted as the little extrusion in the hat is too little to fit on the head and the arm seems to be a bit wonky however that may just be a printer error.

Here is a link to a video demonstrating the final product
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4mjiX3LifCw

Here is the link to my partner's Thingiverse
http://www.thingiverse.com/Rin23333333333

description.text: Designed to be a children's shoe, sized as a 7 girls shoe. The style of the shoe is a sandal that has a larger sole, which is more beneficial for kids to run or play during any activity. It has a flexible strip built into the base to fit the natural bend of the moving foot. It is a combination of a sneaker sole, with a sandal top to allow the foot to breathe and be adjustable for kids to easily put on and take off.

Instructions
  1. Print shoe pair as shown in the STL file
  2. Buy Velcro Strips, Foam support material, and Elastic straps (materials could be subject to change depending on user preference)
  3. Pull elastic straps through triangular holes of the sole of the shoe (may need additional help through tweezers or taped ends)
  4. Follow diagram below to match elastic positions as seen in the renderings (unless user wants the straps positioned differently)
  5. Cut one end off and attach velcro strips
  6. Glue other end into the sole of the shoe
  7. Cut and attach foam support into the heel of the shoe
I designed on 123d

description.text:
This is a set of stackable poker chips that is primarily designed with portability in mind and can be printed without support material. Each chip is 25mm in diameter and 2.5mm in thickness.

Have designed it in a way that is:

  1. interesting to look at,
  2. have a great tactile feel,
  3. makes a nice clink when dropped onto hard surfaces
  4. light and portable
  5. stackable and can withstand minor wobbling (though chip orientation is important to form a tall stack)

You can see how stable the chip stacks are in this video: https://youtu.be/SES53gOOjNQ

Font credit: The numeric font is Alfa Slab One designed by JM Solé

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.15mm

Notes:

No supports are necessary, though can imagine that it may print better with them. Up to how you like them.

Due to small details of the gap in the "0" letter, you would want a slower speed for your first layer and a higher speed for the bridging layer to get the best results.

Designed in OpenJSCAD.

You can view the source code here under the "pokerchips" directory: https://github.com/felixleong/JSCADModels/tree/develop

title: Wanhao Duplicator i3 LED Light Bar

description.text:
This is a light bar that I created myself to make it more easy to see everything on my printer.

It uses a cabinet light bar with the included mounting brackets and screws. This requires NO drilling on the printer and just snaps onto the printer frame. You can use either one or two support bars depending on your preference. I prefer two to make it look better and more stable.

This does not interfere with the max z height

Link to Amazon light bar : http://a.co/f3paslm

I did use the external light bar power supply so I can turn it on and off when I want to so it's on all the time when the printer is on, only when I want it.

Im sure you can use any cabinet light bar you find as long as it has the same bracket and screw.

description.text:
This is a remix of @DanielBull's nice Z probe, hand-modified to fit the "sturdy" variant of Mendel90. It additionally allows for an extra block for adjusting the distance to the X endstop - in my machine, the bolts for the extruder mount go a little further out and would hit the Z axis if left at standard distance.

See the original for installation instructions. There is a gap allowing extra securing of the piece, requiring drilling a small hole into the carriage, then applying an appropriate wood screw.

Anecdote: Trying out early versions of this model, having to dismantle the X belt, showed me just what a big difference proper X tension can make for the print quality. I now tension it to 103Hz.

comments.text:
Nice one!
I now know where to send people that say my design doesn't fit their Mendel :)

A simple acrylic holder to help keep your Pi next to your breadboard. Get prototyping with minimal fuss. Designed for later revisions of Raspberry Pis - with mounting holes. We found that M3 nylon screws work well with the Raspberry Pi mounting holes, and using rubber bumper stickers underneath the Pi to keep it from moving around too much. Especially handy when plugging jumper wires on to the GPIO header pins.  
UPDATE: Use version 02 if you need a file with no fonts, eg. for upload to services such as Ponoko.

description.text:
The dash on my Kawasaki Teryx has a "knockout" for a 12V outlet to be installed. I cut out the hole in the dash per the knockout...but I had not checked the actual diameter of the usb/voltmeter that I assumed was the same size as a 12V outlet.

Holes are 29mm, with a 50mm outside dimension. I think 5 or 6mm thick for the front, and 4 for the rear.

Works fine, and looks like it was made for it.:)

title: Qidi reel holder with locknut - adjustable

description.text:
Update:-

Original file names have changed to say exactly what it is i.e
M48-spindle cap
M48-spindle cap locknut
M48-Dia50.5-spindle

Also another version added for reels with a smaller internal diameter
M30-spindle cap
M30-spindle cap locknut
M30-Dia31-spindle

Everything should be the same otherwise

This is a reel holder with lock nut for a Qidi Tech 1 machine, I'm sure it will fit other machines that are similar in design
The reel holder will adjust to suit reel widths 54mm to 76mm wide, you adjust it to suit and then nip the lock nut up to guarantee the large flanged nut doesnt grip the reel.
It fits most reels I've measured.

The main spindle is 50.5mm diameter and has a modelled M10 thread ready for the stud that came with the machine .The other end is M48 x 5 pitch if I remember rightly.

I've uploaded a slightly tweaked model from suggestions on how it printed and reeels used.

  1. Increased thread length on the main spindle
  2. Increased the length of the spindle plain diameter
  3. Added a chamfer on the inside of the main collar nut

download the v2 versions for increased range of reels that can be used

title: Modular electronics casing for Anet A8 (MOSFET, RPi, 4 relay module, optocoupler)

description.text:
This is a remix of the great electronic casing of c_wolsey! All credits go to c_wolsey.

I found that the original casing was too small (lacking height) for my purpose. I wanted to insert a Raspberry Pi, a MOSFET module for the heatbed and a 4 port relay module and off course the Anet main board but struggled a lot with the original size of the casing. I ended up putting in a lot more, e.g. thicker cables, an optocoupler for the auto level sensor and a connector for the 220V mains.

I noticed (during installing) that if you need to put modules higher or lower you would have to print the whole thing again. You counter that by cutting pillars or make mantle pillars (cilinders with a solid end caps with room for the screw; if you do this properly you can attach the cilinder pillars to the electronic modules and just press them onto the pillars of the casing: works perfectly and makes the modules easy to remove!). One of the foto's show the lid off with the Raspberry Pi (RPi) bungling out with the mantle pillars attached to the RPi.

I ended up tracing the original design and extrude the casing. The base plate is now separated from the side structure. I added the step files so everybody can make his or her adaptions to the base-plate. I encourage you all to modify the base-plate to your exact needs, this pillar configuration works perfectly for me, but might not work for you. If you make an error you now do not need to reprint the whole casing, just the base plate, this saves a lot of time. Notice that large holes for cables are not in the design, you can push them trough the hexagons or just remove some material to enlarge the hexagons.

Note that the lid needs to be printed from c_wolsey's files. I did not bother to add that one.

The casing currently houses:

  • a 4 channel relay module (https://www.aliexpress.com/item/5V-4-Channel-Relay-Module-Shield-for-Arduino-ARM-PIC-AVR-DSP-Electronic-5V-4-Channel/32725782884.html?spm=2114.13010608.0.0.XztqjD)
  • a MOSFET for the heat bed (https://www.aliexpress.com/item/General-Add-on-Heated-Bed-Expansion-Power-Module-High-Power-3D-Printer-Parts/32788291471.html?spm=2114.13010608.0.0.XztqjD)
  • the Anet A8 main board
  • an optocoupler (https://www.aliexpress.com/item/1-Channel-Optocoupler-Isolation-Module-Input-12V-No-Din-Rail-Holder-PLC-Processors-80KHz-PC817-EL817/32719957788.html?spm=2114.10010108.1000023.1.D5PHTa)
  • a Raspberry Pi 2B (running OctoPrint)

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.24

Infill:

-

Assembly
  • Use some small M3 screws to connect the side walls to the bottom plate.
  • Heat up 2 M3 nuts and place them in the nut pockets of the base plate.

Beware of the screw heads of the top lid and the distance to the x-axis stepper. I use high head Allen key screws and washers, for 2 screws I had to remove the washers to prevent the stepper striking against the screws.

comments.text: Hello, I'm curious about your set up. What are you using the 4 channel relay module and the  optocoupler for?
comments.author: Zaebros

comments.text: The Raspberry Pi runs a print server called OctoPrint, which can be interfaced from within your network through a browser interface (even outside your network is possible, but I have not figured that out; that VPN stuff is over my head). OctoPrint runs scripts (Linux shell scripts) to control the 4-channel relay module. Currently I'm using 3 of the 4 relays, one to switch on/off the main voltage that powers the printer PSU (from a menu item in OctoPrint), the second switches on/off a 12V LED strip to illuminate the printer and the third relay switches that annoying fan that cools the extruder (40x40x10mm fan). This fan switches on through scripts that are activated by OctoPrint specific (i.e. custom) G-code commands (e.g. OCTO 100 switches on the fan, and OCTO 110 switches off the fan; these custom G-code commands are implemented before and after print job G-code scripts). Now, when my printer is idle, I do not hear the fan.

remixed_from.author: DrLex
remixed_from.title: Customizable Adjustable Glass Bed Bracket for FlashForge Creator Pro etc

title: Spring-loaded Knobs for Adjustable Glass Bed Bracket

description.text:
These are improved knobs for the Customizable Adjustable Glass Bed Bracket for the FlashForge Creator Pro and similar printers. These knobs have a silicone gasket incorporated in them, which acts as a spring. The problem with the original knobs and many other brackets designs, is that the thermal expansion of the aluminum bed is much larger than that of the glass (especially borosilicate glass). This means if you tighten the knobs while the bed is cold and then heat it, it becomes larger than the glass. This causes the brackets to lose their grip, allowing the glass to shift around.

These spring-loaded knobs solve that problem by keeping on pushing against the brackets even if they move inwards a little due to the bed expanding. The gaskets are just thick enough to offer the required spring travel, without being too thick to make the brackets wobbly.

Some assembly and patience is required: you need to create your own silicone gaskets with a printable mold (or you can try printing them with a flexible filament). I provide molds for 3.5 mm and 4 mm tall gaskets. Which one is most suitable, will depend on how flexible the silicone compound is that you will be using. I suggest to simply print both molds, make two pairs of gaskets, and see which ones work best.
 

How to make the gaskets

Carefully read the instructions on the Customizable Gasket Mold Maker page. In a very short nutshell: print the molds in ABS, as it seems to adhere the least to silicone compound. Use RTV silicone if you can.
If you want even thicker gaskets, you can make your own with Customizer on that page. The inner diameter must be 10 mm and the outer diameter 14.1 mm. You could also try a gasket with a square profile to increase stiffness.

The nice thing is that you can already use the knobs without the gaskets while you're waiting for them to cure. You only need to remember to manually re-tighten the knobs after preheating the bed. Once you have the gaskets, unscrew the knobs, drop in the gaskets, and you're good to go.

Preparing the gaskets for use

Cut or pry off any excess silicone from the gaskets to make them nice and round. Make sure the gaskets are fully cured before assembling the knobs. RTV silicone gaskets should be ready to use, but for regular silicone, you should leave the gaskets in the open air for at least 24 more hours, probably longer for neutral cure compound. This allows them to cure further and release solvents still contained inside. Again, exposing them to humidity may speed up this process.

Alternative: print your gaskets

If you have a sufficiently flexible filament, you may be able to print the gaskets instead. Print a simple hollow cylinder that is about 4 mm tall, with a wall that has a centerline of 12 mm and a thickness of about 3.5 mm. You may need to experiment to find a good shape that allows itself to be squished without blocking the gap. Under-extruding a little may help to get a more flexible result. I haven't tried this, so I can't tell you what the optimal shape is or whether it will work at all, but garyd9 had some success with TPU printed gaskets, see the comments section for more details.

How to use the knobs

Remove any remains of hairspray or glue stick from the bottom of the disks and brackets, to ensure these parts can easily slide against each other, otherwise tightening the knobs could be difficult. A wee bit of silicone grease/oil can help as well, you may need to re-apply this occasionally. Assemble and mount the knobs as shown in the photos.

You can adjust the knobs in two ways:

  1. Preheat the bed to the highest temperature you'll use, and then tighten the knobs just beyond the point where the glass can no longer move.
  2. Just tighten the knobs with the bed cold, to the point where there is only a tiny gap left between the disk and the knob.

Either method is fine, but the first one will minimize the amount of stress on the brackets and could prolong their lifespan. If you're not going to print for a while, it is advisable to loosen one of the knobs.

If you made the gaskets with regular silicone compound, they will be quite soft when freshly made, and become harder over the course of the next weeks. This means you may need to tighten the knobs more with freshly made gaskets.

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

No

Resolution:

0.1 mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

For the knobs: as with the originals, ABS is recommended for heat resistance. Print slowly and if possible, provide moderate cooling to get an accurate result. See the original brackets page for more details.

The knobs are available in both fine and coarse threads, and normal and small sizes, like the originals. Print the knob that matches the pin thread and bracket height you're using. You should print the normal size knobs unless you have a very thin bed that would cause the knobs to stick out above the glass.

For the gasket mold: again see the Customizable Gasket Mold Maker page for instructions. In a very short nutshell: use ABS because it seems the least sticky to the silicone.
To avoid that the tip of the alignment cone becomes a molten blob due to short layer print times, you can try to:

  • print two molds at once. You'll need two gaskets anyway, and making them at once will save you a lot of waiting time. It isn't worth it to try saving a few grams of filament by only printing one mold!
  • print the molds together with something else to increase the time between layers.
  • provide all the cooling you can muster while the cone is being printed.

The reason why I chose silicone gaskets as springs, is that silicone does not easily lose its shape over time, it is quite heat-resistant, and most importantly, everyone can easily make their own gaskets with a 3D printed mold! Any other 3D printed glass bed bracket that relies on springiness of the plastic itself, is pretty much doomed to deform over time when heated near 110°C. These knobs on the other hand should last a long time.

Hello everyone!

*edit: Printing tip: I used a high infill density, to make it a little heavy. I used 50% infill so it does not want to fall over easily. Other than that you can use any settings or filament you like, should work properly.

Another quick design, I used to have my drills in separate smaller containers, but it was a pain to get them out of it, so i decided to make an easy holder for them.

The holes that I created are attached in the picture, but to make it easier to read here they are from top row to bottom row, left to right:

8,2mm - 6,2mm - 5,2mm -- 8,2mm - 6,2mm - 5,2mm
2,2mm - 3,2mm - 4,2mm -- 2,2mm - 3,2mm - 4,2mm

Now you might ask, why is it ,2mm bigger? This accounts for printing error. the use for this item is to easily grab any drill, and I would not like to use both my hands to pull 1 drill out.

If any of your drills do not fit, do not worry! Just drill them out with the drill that needs to fit in it!

description.text:
Update: 5/24/2017

  • Added locking mechanism to secure switch
  • Added switchrest-lock.stl (locking mechanism)
  • Modified switchrest-left and switchrest-right brackets
  • Added switchrest-complete.stl (all components ready to print in a single stl file)

I highly suggest you do some post processing on the locks either sand or file the portion that locks into the rails before using this or you will have a hard time getting them off and possibly break the side rails.

Once you can insert/remove the locks easily proceed to insert your Switch.

With these last changes I consider this completed and I don't plan on making further edits, suggestions are always welcomed.

Enjoy.

Update: 5/15/17

  • Added SwitchRest and Switch logos
  • Added angled bracket so switch air intake has breathing room to prevent overheating
  • Added correct printing position for all STLs
  • Added SwitchRest-Left-Right STL contains both brackets ready to print in correct position

I made this so my daughter could play the Nintendo Switch mounted to my cars headrest while we do road trips.

This is my initial prototype which I made in 1 hour so I might be making a few revisions but this works really well, we recently used it on a 4 hour trip and it withstood all the bumps you normally have when driving on the highway at 70mph.

I suggest you do a solid infill for best durability since these can be a bit tight when placing them on the switch and need a decent amount of force to be removed.

description.text:
My take on a Quadcopter frame. It's intended for 8.5x20mm coreless motors and a micro F3 flight controller. I have yet to buy the parts so the design may change to accommodate the electronics. Design was based on looking around at different quad frames and I liked a sort of hybrid X frame quad with an organic look. I think it looks a bit like a beetle so that is where the name came from.

Parts needed.

4x m3 nylon screws
4x m3 20mm standoffs (spacer)

This is an iPad Mini Tabletop stand designed to hold iPad Mini at a slight reclined angle in landscape orientation. It may also work for full size iPads or other tablets as well (but I have not tested this.) Design is very strong but uses relatively little plastic due to structural girder-like design with fillets at intersections.
Easy to snap off supports are integrated into the design (they are not shown in the rendering above) to allow the horizontal beams to print in the air above the printing platform in both .thing and .STL files. Highly recommend using a raft if you are going to print directly from .STL.
Normal print settings were used in Makerware (rafts option checked, do not check the box to have Makerware add additional supports!) I did notice a slight drooping of the PLA material on the underside of the upper diagonal member located on the sides of the holder but the drooping is not really noticeable unless you turn the stand over. The drooping of material could be eliminated or reduced by printing at higher layer resolution settings.
Printed in at normal resolution default settings with raft.  Has custom made supports to help print horizontal struts without droop (not shown in rendering of stand).  Printing takes about 2 hours.

title: Tripteron three axis fused filament fabrication printer or pick and place robot
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is a minor remix of Apsu's Tripteron 3d printer. The Tripteron is a three axis robot design at and patented by Université Laval in Quebec City, Quebec, Canada. It is reposted here for experimental and personal use. Commercial use will require a license negotiated with the university, at a minimum. I am not a lawyer, and if you intend commercial use, consult one.

Due to price and experience considerations, I do this kind of design in Sketchup. To make a model of Apsu's Tripteron and modify it in the way I was hoping to make it, I imported the STL files provided by Apsu, and recreated them inside of Sketchup. This is mostly because sketchup is limited in the detail it can support. I also imported a model of the rails that Apsu used and recreated those as well. There is an existing Sketchup model of a 2020 extrusion. This was used for modeling the extrusions in the model.

In Apsu's design, the X and Y axis rails were along the front and side, with the bottom of the Z axis opposite the shared corner for the X and Y axis.

The primary advantage of the Tripteron robot design is that the three axis are independent and the location of the linear slide for each axis can be left mostly up to the designer.

I chose to have the Y axis along the left side, the X axis along the back side, and Z axis along the right back side because it would allow for the front, right side, and bottom to be mostly open.

The Z axis is intended to be run by a lead screw or a ball-screw arrangement. The other axis were to continue to use belt drive. To accommodate the change in the location of the Z axis, six 305 mm extrusions were used, four for the bottom square, and two for the upper bracing.

The three corner extrusions were extended by forty mm to allow for a 305 mm square inside space for each of the three faces created by the extrusion pieces. This allows for two point five mm of space on either end of the X and Y axis rails.

The corner braces (bracket-right-angle) were modified to add an arch along the long side to allow for better clearance of the X and Y arms at maximum travel. This modification was added to the X and Y motor mount.

I was concerned with the rigidity of the "shoulder" mount which connects the axis slide to the axis arm, and created a ramp from the far end of the shoulder up to the top of the mounting location of the 608 bearings for this joint.

The shoulder to elbow section of each arm consists of a joint-inline-fork at one end, a 2020 extrusion of 175 mm length and finally a joint-inline-tongue section.

The elbow to wrist section of the Y and Z axis arms consists of a joint-right-angle-fork section, a 2020 extrusion of 175 mm length and finally a join-inline-fork section. The corresponding X axis section replaces the 175 mm length extrusion with a 150 mm length extrusion.

The design as originally uploaded has bracing added between the front left corner and the back right corner on the bottom. This is intended for 3d printer application with a printing bed inserted between the four rails of the bottom square.

For use as a pick and place robot, the intent is for the front and right bottom rails to be removed so that the board to be populated can be placed from the front of the unit, and the component rolls and pickup area can be off to the right of the unit.

In trying to figure some things out, I noticed that the point directly below the tool head, with the changes I made to Apsu's geometry, wasn't exactly in the middle of the work area. Infact, with a 10 inch (254 mm) square work area, it would have overlapped with the Y axis shoulder by a little more than an eighth of an inch (4 mm). I've designed a replacement for the tool head nearly from scratch, and have the option of mounting a NEMA 11* motor pointing down to the work area. This will be quite helpful for mounting a hollow shaft motor on the tool head to act as an A (rotary) axis for component rotation and plumbing the suction for the "pick" and "place" part of the pick and place. Also, this means that the "short" fore-arm on the Y axis can be replaced with the "long" fore-arm, and removes the requirement for the 150mm 2020 extrusion.

(Sorry, the end effector has room for a NEMA 11 motor, not a NEMA 17 motor.)

comments.text: I fail to see any benefit in this cinematic for a 3D printer or even a pick and place machine.
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text: One benefit is that because the print area does not move, the total printer volume doesn't have to be much larger than the build volume.  If a printer moves the print bed in the x, y, or x and y axis, this requires that the printer be more than twice the travel in the affected axis.  My Velleman K8200 moves the print bed in the x and y axis.  For an eight inch (200 mm) square print area on the print bed, the printer ends up being two feet (610 mm) by one and a half feet (450 mm).  With the 300 mm rails, there is approximately ten and a quarter inches (260 mm) of travel for each axis.  To give us a little margin for error, with out having checked the kinematics (due to lack of my skill) or having actually constructed this machine, I'm expecting that a ten by ten by ten inch (254 mm sided cube) build volume is reasonable.  The Tripteron model as published is approximately seventeen inches (430 mm) square in desktop foot print.  K8200: Approximately 432 square inches (0.27 meters square) of desktop space, and 64 square inches (0.02 meters square) of x-y build area.  Tripteron: 289 square inches (0.20 meters square) of desktop space, and 100 square inches (0.06 meters square) of x-y build area.

comments.text:
No problem to have the Z moving, it is a slow mvt. On the other hand I see a lot more mass, plenty of pivoting points for the X, Y where lightweight, rigidity are keys.

For pick and place how does it compare to a Delta ?

comments.text: In no particular order.
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text:
To be Cartesian or not is irrelevant considering today microcontroller processing power. Resolution of Delta type is good enough. There is an issue I foresee here regarding repeatability too du to the arm flexing and number of articulation that require high class components. This may lead to an excessive cost for a FFM 3D printer.
So, the best is you build one from off the shelf components and present the result. I am open, curious and have also looked at plenty of other different kinematics.
And don't convert, design and build it in metric to keep the cost down and be accepted in the world. I have seen Canadian made industrial sawmills with a mix of metric and "inch" parts and strongly advised against buying them to avoid downtime because of parts availability and potential mix up :-)

title: Bluetooth Wireless Editable Gcode Sender (Remote control for your 3D Printer)

description.text:
Update 6/3/2017: Updated the Arduino Sketch file to correct the feedrates of the axis movements. Now the feedrates of Z, Y, Z, E are set independently, especially the Extruder feedrate.

This project is very much like using Pronterface or Repetier Host manual control to send gcode instructions to your printer while connected to the computer via USB cable, but instead using a programmable wireless bluetooth remote instead of a computer.

Note: Older wired version can be found here. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2105847

Remote is built up with an Arduino Nano connected to two small 16 button keypads (32 keys total) as well as a serial bluetooth adapter/interface. Each button can send a single line of gcode or a script of multiple lines.

ZIp file included containing the Arduino sketch, wiring diagrams, and setup guides for the components of the system.

Gcode sender is intended to work for 3D printers as well as a CNC mills and laser engravers. Any machine that uses gcode.

This setup allows one to send highly customized gcode scripts/macros to the printer with a push of a button. I've tested all of the scripts I included in the sketch. Any one of them can be replaced, moved, and edited.

In the sketch, i tired to include a lot of comments to make it easier to tweak the code to suit your own needs.

Communication between Gcode Sender and printer is through serial communication (Tx, Rx) using a serial Bluetooth adapters (no cables). On RAMPS style boards the AUX-1 port can be used on the printer side. Specifics on wiring can be found in the zip file. In Repetier firmware, I had to enable Bluetooth serial port to make use of the AUX-1 port.

The STLs print without support. NOTE: The STLs were designed to print with a low infill. The infill is basically the support for the body to keep its shape while printing. Keep the infill low to not waste filament.

Once assembled the Arduino Nano board is hidden inside the STL body in the cavity under the keypads. The kaypads have a sticky backing that is attached to the insert STL. The insert can be later removed (a print removal tools works great) if you need to reprogram the Nano at any time. The insert is kept in place with friction-no glue.

Fusion 360 file provided to further tweak the Keypad holder parts. PLEASE DO let me know if you create alternative designs for the Gcode Sender.

BOM:

  • (2x) 16 key 4x4 membrane keypad.
  • (1x) Arduino Nano Development Board (selected because it has enough i/o pins for two keypads without any additional shields-pro mini does not). 1 keypad can be readily used instead of two.
  • Jumper cables to connect keypads to the Arduino nano board. 8 pins per keypad. And bluetooth adapters. 4 pins per bluetooth module.
  • (2x) Serial Bluetooth Modules. HC-05. Search Aliexpress.com for "HC-05". One will be setup as master, the other as slave. (note HC-06 can replace one of the HC-05. HC-06 is only slave, whereas HC-05 can be either master or slave.)
  • (1x) mini rocker on/off switch, 2 pins
  • DIY vinyl adhesive label. Custom label to put over the buttons. Sample file included.
  • Power pack of your choosing. Various suggestions include: 4x rechargeable AA/AAA cells, or a small 5v power bank (those used for charging cell phones on the go, but if using this option the trouble will be in splicing in an on/off switch), or a 18650 battery pack. If using 18650 cells, you can wire two in parallel and use a step up converter; or you can wire two in series. In either case, use a Battery Management System (BMS) AKA protection circuit, for protecting against over charging and over discharging the 18650 cells. Dont use unprotected 18650 cells.

Left keypad Explained (Keypad 1):

  • The idea is to first select which Axis to work with (e.g. x,y,z,e) then select the movement resolution amount (e.g. 0.1, 1, 10, etc), then the movement direction button (+ or -). Movement direction button can be held down to continue movement in that direction.
Fusion 360 file included.

description.text:
Most public waterways require all boats to display navigation lights after dark. Get in some night paddling using this Thing.

When glued to a rigid base, this thing can hold a 2mm thick card vertically. The card can be fitted with the Life Gear light holders from maushammer. After printing and testing the first version (V1), I wished it had a support so it did not depend so much on the glue's adhesion. I've included version two (V2) to address this concern.

The card can be affixed to the holder by either using a short M3 screw, or by drilling a hole through the card and putting some stiff wire through the three holes.

I've used a piece of thick aluminum flashing for the base and a piece of aluminum wire to hold the base to the board. The red light goes on the port side, green light goes on the starboard side.

Feel free to make changes to the model by using this link.

title: Nickel Fidget Spinners (C Bearing and 608 Bearing versions)

description.text:
Two versions of my Nickel spinners. Each one holds 9 nickels for the weights. One version uses a C size yoyo bearing and the other uses a 608 size skateboard bearing.

I do 4 solid top and bottom layers with 30% infill for the spinner body and 50% infill for the buttons

Spinners do not need supports, but the buttons do for the recessed thumb indent. I like to fill the indents with flowable silicon when they are finished for nice grips.

All of the holes for the nickels and bearings are a VERY tight fit so you need to press them in with a press or hammer them in but they need to be tight like that to hold the bearings and nickels in without them falling out.

Enjoy and happy spinning!!

Printer:

Jumpstart3D

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

30%-50%

author: fattminer

title: QSN - 3D Printer Torture Test Art (Quasicrystalline Spin Network)

description.text:
This is the QSN (Quasicrystalline Spin Network.)

First and foremost, Please watch the video attached so you have most of the information you need to print this. :

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AHH-6EqQCB4

Second, This is my challenge to the 3D printing community, Can you Print it?

I spent over 3 months trying to get this to print extremely well. It took all kinds tweaks and Tests, BUT the very first one I tried WORKED! So i know you can do it too. after you get one printed, its all tweaking from there! How much better can you make it? I have about 30 of them Printed now. each with a new tweak!

My coworker Ray had this pulled up on his screen when I went into his office and I said, "I think I can print that"... and 3 months later here we are!

I spent way to much time trying to tune my built from scratch Restock delta to make perfect prints of the QSN. I eventually achieved this goal. Now I can print some really amazing prints of the QSN.

This is no easy print, however, I really would LOVE feed back from others who try to print one. I'm interested in seeing your method of printing this. Things such as:

How did you generate support?
What printer you are using?
What filaments did you try?
What slicers did you get to work?
Were you able to generate a solid?
Anything else you think would be helpful to share!

I have had almost No luck making this a solid. It's currently "stick and balls". You will need to make sure your slicer can handle that. I did get Meshmixer to make it a water tight solid, but it has to many triangles. Its almost overloaded for most average computers. You need a lot of ram.
So if you try this, use the stick and balls version, and make sure your slicer can handle it.

If you have any luck making this a solid please let me know.

Something I did not mention in the video was that I did try to build custom supports in Meshmixer as well as PreForm, but it was not achievable. Please give it a go and let me know if you get custom supports to work.

Challenge excepted ? :)

I'm not giving out my slicer settings just yet, because I'm interested in how you get it to work best! Later I will publish my Slicer settings that I have. However, in reality each system will be different any how and require your own settings...

You can find more of my 3D printing research here:
http://rwgresearch.com/open-projects/3d-printing-research/

Much Love & God Bless,

~Russ Gries

My YouTube(s)...
Main Content:
https://www.youtube.com/user/rwg42985

Live 3D printing & Stuff...
https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC0JRhK5DUp4Mr_WgNBnV57A

Time laps:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0P8dOWKQtLE

This Was Awesome! Showing Angus & Joel the QSN in Person!
https://youtu.be/pPpDE4XCC9Q

Custom Rostock (Built in 2012)

Notes:

only use raft if you dont get good bed adhesion. use 1 layer and less Than 50% infill. works for me...

Some filament I used:

green PLA
https://www.matterhackers.com/store/3d-printer-filament/pro-series-green-pla-filament-1.75mm?rcode=RWG3D

Translucent Red
https://www.matterhackers.com/store/3d-printer-filament/red-translucent-pro-series-pla-filament-1.75mm?rcode=RWG3D

Ray Did The Math, Russ Did Some Small changes...

We build the QSN by taking a cuboctahedron, an Archimedean solid made of 8 triangular faces and 6 square faces, and 12 vertices, and keep only 4 triangular faces, not touching one another, built on the 12 vertices.
We link these 4 triangles to the center and get 4 tetrahedra sharing a vertex in the center, the basis of a FCC lattice.
We translate each tetrahedron along an edge bringing the center to an external vertex, and repeat the operation, getting an FCC lattice.
Then, we “Fibonacci-space” this lattice, by inserting gaps of the edge size divided by the golden ratio, such that each ray emanating from the center becomes a Fibonacci chain. We get a Fibonacci-spaced FCC lattice.
Then we duplicate this lattice 4 more times, to finally get 5 copies; and we rotate four of the five copies, such that the 20 tetrahedra sharing the center aligns all their faces in only 10 planes.
There is two ways to get there, and the object made of the 20 tetrahedra in the center becomes a 20-group, a geometric figure discovered by our team some years ago.
The two ways assign a chirality to the object, and to the compound of the 5 Fibonacci-spaced FCC lattices. We choose one of the two possible chiralities.
We have later found that the 60 vertices of the 20 central tetrahedra are the vertices of the regular compound of 5 cuboctahedra (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Compound_of_five_cuboctahedra )
And more recently we have found that the cuboctahedron is the Dirichlet sphere of radius square root of 2, while the 20-group is the next Dirichlet sphere of radius square root of 8, where we have defined the Dirichlet spheres as the spheres whose 3D radius is equal to the 6D radius, if x,y,z are Dirichlet integers of the form a+b phi (a, b integer and phi the golden ratio), and restrict to regular tetrahedra made of one equilateral triangle on the sphere and the fourth vertex at the center, which explain their non-arbitrary algebraic emergence.
Now that we have this superposition of 5 differently oriented Fibonacci-spaced FCC, otherwise seen as a bunch of regular tetrahedra, which we name our possibility space, we select only from the available vertices, the ones which are themselves centers of 20-groups: they become a set of vertices.
We automatically select all the pairs of this vertices which are at two possible distances, one being golden ratio times the other. These edges are what is 3D printed.
We check that they are organized as a set of dodecahedra, and two sets of icosahedra, the larger edge to the smaller being the golden ratio.
You can search and find this dodecahedra and icosahedra in the QSN.
Because of the limited combinatoric ways of connecting this edges and the fact that all the space is covered, this is a 3D quasicrystal.
Our team has also published many relationships between this quasicrystal and the Elser-Sloane quasicrystal obtained by projecting the E8 lattice, which links it to particle physics.

~Raymond Aschheim

For more read this paper:
https://arxiv.org/pdf/1511.07786.pdf

YOU are responsible for any damage caused by attempting to 3D Print these files! Always keep an eye on your 3D Printers when attempting challenging prints.

FAIL's ( only a few) but finaly it works!

description.header: Deeper Look At What The QSN is.
description.text:
The QSN or Quasicrystalline Spin Network is a 3D representation of a 4D quasicrystal, called the Elser-Sloane Quasicrystal, which is created by projecting the E8 lattice to 4D. This 4D quasicrystal is made entirely of regular, 3D tetrahedra, which is achieved due to the particular angle of the E8 to 4D projection. When we take any five, 3D subspaces of this 4D quasicrystal (one subspace being all tetrahedra that are oriented in the same direction) and then rotate them from one another by 15.552* degrees, we come up with a 3D quasicrystal that can be seen as a representation of the 4D, Elser-Sloane quasicrystal. We call this new, 3D quasicrystal the “compound quasicrystal.” Why is the compound quasicrystal important? It is important because of its relationship to the QSN.

The QSN is the densest possible 3D network of point-sharing Fibonacci chains and is the most computationally efficient point space in 3D. It is created by taking the FCC lattice (a point space that provides the densest packing of 3D spheres) and then spreading its points until they are spaced according to the Fibonacci sequence. We then take this new lattice of Fibonacci spaced points, clone it five times and rotate the five clones from one another by 15.522 degrees to create the QSN.

As it turns out, the compound quasicrystal is an exact subspace of the QSN: the QSN contains all legal configurations of the Elser-Sloane, E8-to-4D quasicrystal.

The QSN therefore is deeply related to the E8 lattice and its 4D projection.

http://www.quantumgravityresearch.org/portfolio/the-quasicrystalline-spin-network-2

description.text:
Keyhole Pocket Inserts for woodworking and DIY projects.

You will need a 1" Forstner style drill bit. A 25mm (1" = 25.4mm) could work but will be much tighter.
The recess (hole) will need to be 1/4" (6.5mm) deep for a flush fit.
I suggest using a drill press for the hole but can be carefully done by hand.

The insert will be very tight and has ridges around the outside to grip the wood.
It will (probably) need to be hammered into place.
Get it right the first time because they are very hard to remove once installed.

Also provided are two screw holes that fit #6 wood screws nicely. These will only be needed if you have the need for extra holding.
The insert could also be glued in... an epoxy would probably work well.

The keyhole is designed to accept the head and thread width of at least a #8 pan head screw. They are the common size of screw used with plastic drywall inserts. The keyhole also features a thicker area where the screw seats into place... This should make for easier installation by leaving the wall screw just a little "loose" but will tighten as the as the object is seated into place.

Let me know if you try these and how they work out.... Thanks.

description.text:
hartk1213's didn't fit on my keymod rail, so I modified his design so it would. I also made it slightly more ergonomic by rounding corners and making the handstop smoother. The keymod hole snaps should fit without any modification, and they're slightly springy so they'll stay in place. On my rail they're very tight, not coming off by themselves.

The handstop is slightly different in the picture, I made it fit in the same amount of space as one of the normal covers for the model.

You may have to sand the keymod snaps depending on how thick your keymod rail is.

For best printing, print with beak oriented upward. Scaled to life size.

Allows you to use standard 120mm fans. Optimized for easy printing. Heatsink is 32mm high. Uses standard case fan screws to attach to fan.

Offset Type 1(A/B): The adapter adds 2mm to heatsink. Fan is offset at one corner. The footprint falls within 95x95mm zone at two sides, so it will fit with high profile RAM. Type A/B are mirrored of each other. Download the STL and see which type you need.

Center Type 1: The adapter DOES NOT add any height to heatsink. It is dead centered, low profile. It will only clear naked ram, or very low profile ram like Corsair LPX.

Center Type 2: The adapter DOES NOT add any height to heatsink. It allows you to offset up to 14mm in direction parallel to the attachment indent on the heatsink, while being centered in the other direction. It will only clear naked RAM or very low profile ram like Corsair LPX.

If you have issues with fitment or have feedback, please comment or message me.

comments.text: I printed the Offset Type 1A. I use it in the Node 202 and it works perfectly, I'm currently using the NF-F12 with it. Thank you so much for making this!
